featured.text: Scientists found that sharp corners are natural weak spots where stress concentrates.
This particular bell, ringing in F sharp, is considered one of the most harmonically beautiful in Europe.
With hot stoves, boiling water and sharp knives at hand, it is understandable that parents don’t want children in the kitchen when they’re making dinner.
In the early 1900s, versions of the British traffic lights appeared in big cities in America, where traffic was on a sharp rise.

other.text: It takes more time to carve with razor-sharp chisels.
They are trapped by the sharp branches of the tea trees.
Since the orange trees suffered _____ damage from a storm in the summer, the farmers are expecting a sharp decline in harvests this winter.
The Amazons are completely dependent on their slaves ____(29)___ their sharp jaws, so well suited for fighting, are useless in taking care of larvae or for digging.
Ice sculptors also use razor-sharp chisels that are specifically designed for cutting ice.

definition.en_def: Having an edge or point that is able to cut or pierce something; quick-witted or perceptive.
definition.example: Be careful with that knife; it's very sharp.
